intro: Phyllanthus graveolens, commonly known as the wild pear or Indian pear, is a shrub native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa, Asia, and the Pacific. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its simple, alternate leaves that are often gland-dotted. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers followed by fleshy, orange-red berries that are edible but have a mild, sweet scent. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in disturbed areas or along roadsides. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal uses, it is cultivated in various parts of the world.
